contentfulBlogPost.title: The Numbers Are High but Improving: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Feb 4

childMarkdownRemark.html: Mandy Brown is editorial lead at The COVID Tracking Project. She previously served as VP of Product at Vox Media.
Nicki Camberg is a student journalist studying Political Science and Statistics at Barnard College, and the City Data Manager at CTP.
Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Alice Goldfarb leads The COVID Tracking Project’s part in The COVID Racial Data Tracker, and is a Nieman Visiting Fellow.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Kara Oehler is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.

Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

Sarah R. McLaughlin is volunteer at the COVID Tracking Project supporting various data visualization initiatives. She has a background in Epidemiology/Biostatistics and is currently working at a Boston-based SaaS company.
Kara Oehler is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Aarushi Sahejpal is a Shift Lead on Long-Term Care and City Data at the COVID Tracking Project. She also studies International Relations & Data Science at American University

Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Vaccines Begin to Arrive as Cases and Deaths Keep Rising: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Dec 16

lede.lede: Cases are up and known deaths in long-term-care facilities are the highest they’ve been since late May.

blog_post.title: Our Final Week: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Mar 4

lede.lede: Tests are up, while cases, hospitalizations, and deaths continue their declines. We are at a crucial moment in the pandemic, with vaccinations ramping up but multiple variants of SARS-CoV-2 gaining footholds across the US. In our final weekly report, we urge continued vigilance in reducing the spread of the virus, and direct readers on how to follow the course of the pandemic without us.

blog_post.title: Good News Despite Data Wobbles: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Feb 25

lede.lede: Cases, hospitalizations, and deaths are still declining, though holiday reporting and winter storms have probably caused fluctuations in several metrics. We reiterate that deaths reported each day don’t represent people who died that day—and they may even include deaths that occurred several months ago. And now is the time to switch over to federal data sources, because The COVID Tracking Project has only a little over a week of data compilation left.

blog_post.title: More Good News: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Feb 18

lede.lede: Case numbers are dropping rapidly, and deaths are down 20 percent from last week. Vaccines are finally showing up in the data with dramatic declines in deaths from long-term-care facilities. We urge caution about interpreting wobbles in the data in the next week or two, given storm disruptions affecting Texas and elsewhere.

blog_post.title: The Third Surge Continues to Ease: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Feb 11

lede.lede: Another week of good news: Cases and hospitalizations continue to drop nationally, and deaths are down for the second week in a row. We’re concerned about ambiguous indicators in the Northeast, and about testing declines.

blog_post.title: The Numbers Are High but Improving: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Feb 4

lede.lede: Cases and hospitalizations continue to drop, and now COVID-19 deaths finally appear to be declining.

blog_post.title: Outbreaks Ease Across the US, but Our Numbers Are Still Very High: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Jan 28

lede.lede: COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations are dropping in almost every state—and dropping very quickly in some of our worst-hit areas. Hospitalizations are down another 10 percent but are still far above levels seen in previous surges. Deaths, which lag behind cases and hospitalizations, remain high.

lede.lede: With holiday reporting backlogs finally (mostly) behind us, we are seeing good signs in every region of the country.

blog_post.title: Soaring Death Numbers and Highly Regional Outbreaks: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Jan 14

lede.lede: Deaths are 25 percent higher than any other week since the pandemic began. Arizona has the worst per-capita new case numbers in the world. A month after the country’s first vaccinations for COVID-19, we still don’t have federal data showing who is receiving the vaccine.

blog_post.title: Record Hospitalizations Point to Trouble in California and the South: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Jan 6

lede.lede: The lingering effects of holiday data reporting are still making most COVID-19 metrics hard to contextualize this week. Hospitalization reporting remains relatively steady and suggests that outbreaks are lighting up across the US South. In Southern California and Arizona, the situation remains dire.

blog_post.title: All Eyes on Hospitalizations: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 30

lede.lede: Holiday reporting has garbled most metrics. Going by current COVID-19 hospitalizations, outbreaks in the Midwest are still easing, but every other region is in trouble.

blog_post.title: In the Deadliest Month Yet, the Pandemic Is Regional Again: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 23

lede.lede: Three weeks in, we’ve seen more COVID-19 deaths in December than in any other month in the US pandemic. This milestone comes as the nationwide surge in cases has subsided back into regional variation: We see positive signs throughout the Midwest but worrying indicators in the South and West. California alone reported nearly 300,000 new cases this week.

blog_post.title: A Vaccine Arrives as Deaths Rise and Southern California Cases Soar: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 17

lede.lede: The news this week is extremely mixed: In the Midwest, cases and hospitalizations are falling. California reported a quarter of a million cases this week, and in Los Angeles County, one in 80 people has COVID-19. More than 50,000 Black Americans have died of COVID-19 as we near 300,000 total US COVID-19 deaths. The first doses of vaccine have arrived in hospitals and on their way to most US nursing homes, where cases continue to rise.

blog_post.title: Our Worst Week Yet: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 10

lede.lede: Reported COVID-19 deaths hit all-time daily and weekly highs this week, and cases and hospitalizations continue to rise.

lede.lede: Long-term-care facilities continue to bear the brunt of this deadly virus. The latest surge continues in the Midwest and South, as COVID-19 cases in the Northeast and West begin to spike.

blog_post.title: Hospitalizations Break 100,000, Holiday Data Stalls Out: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 3

lede.lede: Three of our four topline COVID-19 metrics are still recovering from data interruptions over the Thanksgiving holiday weekend. Meanwhile, hospitalizations are soaring.

blog_post.title: Long-Term Care Deaths Pass 100,000 as Outbreaks Surge: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Dec 2

lede.lede: Despite messy reporting due to the Thanksgiving holiday, this week saw continued high numbers of cases and deaths in long-term care communities. But relief may be on the way, as a CDC committee recommended that long-term care residents and staff be first in line to receive the coronavirus vaccine.

blog_post.title: Midwest Outbreaks Pause, Hospitalizations and Deaths Keep Rising: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Nov 25

lede.lede: US states reported 1.2 million cases, and on three of the past seven days, the number of reported deaths exceeded 2,000. Nearly 90,000 people are hospitalized with COVID-19. After weeks of sharp rises, cases are declining in the Midwest.

blog_post.title: One Million Cases in Seven Days: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Nov 19

lede.lede: Weekly cases grew 26 percent and nearly 80,000 people in the United States are hospitalized with COVID-19. That’s one-third higher than the nation’s previous record.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: A Nationwide Case Surge Hits US Hospitals: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Nov 12

lede.lede: One in 378 US residents tested positive for COVID-19 this week, and hospitalizations have nearly doubled in the past two weeks. The United States is posting new records for cases and hospitalizations nearly every day, and healthcare systems are reaching capacity in many areas where cases have spiked.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Cases Still Rising, Hospitalizations Spiking, Nursing Homes in Trouble: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Nov 5

lede.lede: COVID-19 is surging in large midwestern states while continuing to burn through heavily rural states in the Mountain West. Testing growth has slowed, and new outbreaks are rising in long-term care facilities. Nationally, deaths are up 8 percent, and on Wednesday the United States broke 100,000 new cases a day.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Third Surge Brings Record-Breaking Case Rates Across the Nation, This Week in COVID-19 Data, Oct 29

lede.lede: Unlike the spring and summer outbreaks, the third surge is geographically dispersed, and counts are up in every region of the country. An increase in testing is not sufficient to explain the numbers.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: The Third Surge Worsens as Hospitalizations and Deaths Rise Nationwide. Plus a New Tool for Understanding Racial Data: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Oct 22

lede.lede: The surge in COVID-19 cases spread across the Midwest as Illinois and Indiana saw case growth alongside neighbors Wisconsin and the Dakotas. Hospitalizations rose in 39 US states, and nationally, deaths began to climb once again.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: The Third Surge Has Arrived. Plus, Updates on Data from Long-Term Care Facilities: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Oct 15

lede.lede: Fall has brought a third surge of COVID-19. The data across US regions moved in tandem this week as case and hospitalization numbers rose almost everywhere.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Nadia Zonis is a New York City-based writer and editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Worrisome Data as the Weather Turns: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Oct 8

lede.lede: An outbreak in the White House has turned attention away from the broader outlines of the pandemic. However, cases nationally rose for the fourth consecutive week and hospitalizations have followed, causing serious strain on some states’ health care systems.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Joanna Pearlstein is an editorial lead at the Covid Tracking Project and a former editor at WIRED and Protocol.

blog_post.title: Good News in the Big Picture, but Regional and Weekly Views More Troubling: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Oct 1

lede.lede:
Cases in the Dakotas and Wisconsin continue their troubling rise, but in September the average daily number of cases, hospitalizations, and deaths fell nationwide. 

After a difficult summer, averaged metrics for August and September showed drops in COVID-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths at the national level. At the same time, indicators in a few states are ringing alarm bells, and this week’s data continues a three-week rise in cases, with hospitalizations starting to increase as well.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Joanna Pearlstein is an editorial lead at the Covid Tracking Project and a former editor at WIRED and Protocol.

blog_post.title: Trends Improve Except in the Midwest: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 24

lede.lede: The Midwest and certain Western states showed a rise in case numbers and an uptick in hospitalizations, even as other regions continued to decline. The US reported over 6 million weekly tests for the first time this year, though some states are now lumping antigen tests results into standard PCR test data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Testing In Limbo, Hospitalizations and Deaths Still Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 10

lede.lede: A long holiday weekend makes ambiguous testing data even harder to understand, but hospitalizations are dropping, which is good.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Joanna Pearlstein is an editorial lead at the Covid Tracking Project and a former editor at WIRED and Protocol.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Holiday Reporting Lags Interrupt Positive Trends: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 17

lede.lede: Though cases are rising in parts of the Midwest, hospitalizations in the West and South continued trending downward. The Labor Day holiday impacted data reporting lag times both this week and last, obscuring what had been positive trends in September.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.

blog_post.title: Cases Stop Dropping and the Midwest Heats Up: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 3

lede.lede: After five straight weeks of sharp declines in new cases of COVID-19 in the United States, we’ve leveled off again. Reported tests are up about 5 percent, but are actually dropping in the Midwest, where three states—Iowa, North Dakota, and South Dakota—are driving an uptick in new cases. This week we also launched a new dataset that looks closely at the toll of COVID-19 in nursing homes and other long-term care facilities.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Testing Looks Shaky But National Progress Continues: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 27

lede.lede: New COVID-19 cases continued their steady decline this week, a positive signal supported by a similar decline in hospitalized patients. Reported deaths also fell for the second straight week. Though testing across the US can’t seem to regain the peak of late July, we believe conditions on the ground are improving across the country—and that the data states report is, by and large, trustworthy. Read on to find out why.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Finally, Some Good News. This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 20

lede.lede: Key data points in our COVID-19 tracking are finally beginning to trend positively. In the South, tests rose while cases fell, a pattern not seen there since early spring. Hospitalizations fell for the third week straight, but deaths remained above 1,000 a day on average.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Tests, Cases, and Hospitalizations Keep Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 13

lede.lede: Testing continues to fall, especially in the South, one of the areas where the country needs it the most. Cases, too, are falling, which remains hard to interpret, given the testing decline—but fewer people are now in the hospital with COVID-19 than last week. This is the second week in a row that hospitalizations seem to have dropped, which suggests that infections may be declining independently of testing reductions.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: The Last Thing We Need Is Fewer Tests: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 6

lede.lede: This week’s data marks a return to ambiguities we last saw in April and May. For the first time, we saw week-over-week testing numbers fall—and this decline makes drops in new COVID-19 case numbers difficult to interpret. Deaths continued their steady rise. And new complications like technical glitches and school reopenings threaten to cloud the picture even further.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Cases Declining, Deaths Rising, Hospital Data Remains a Question Mark: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 30

lede.lede: This week’s data brings the first good news in several weeks: new cases of COVID-19 are declining nationally, thanks to substantial declines in reported cases by states with major outbreaks. Deaths, which lag cases, continue to rise. And hospital data is still unreliable for the second week in a row.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Erratic Hospital Numbers, Deaths Still Rising: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 23

lede.lede: The rise in new cases is slowing, but so is testing growth. Hospitalization data was highly erratic this week, but what we did see is alarming. Deaths are rising three weeks behind cases, which suggests a very difficult few weeks ahead for the United States.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: The Unchecked Rise in Cases Turns Deadly: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 16

lede.lede: The US is approaching half a million new cases of COVID-19 each week. States with major outbreaks including Arizona, California, Florida, and Texas all saw record high weekly hospitalizations and deaths. Meanwhile, worsening outbreaks in many other states threaten to increase the pandemic's death toll in the coming weeks.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Alice Goldfarb leads The COVID Tracking Project’s part in The COVID Racial Data Tracker, and is a Nieman Visiting Fellow.

blog_post.title: Record New Cases, Surging Hospitalizations, Rising Deaths: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 9

lede.lede: The South continues to be the epicenter of surges in both cases and hospitalizations. In Arizona, Florida, South Carolina, and Texas, COVID-19 deaths have begun to climb following jumps in new cases. And for the first time since April, deaths are rising nationally.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.

blog_post.title: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 2: Across the US, Outbreaks Are Catching Fire

lede.lede: The US has broken its record for new COVID-19 cases three times in the last week. Thirteen states broke their new-case records since Sunday. In the states with the worst outbreaks, hospitalizations and deaths are rising.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 25: The US Pandemic Is Surging in the South and West

lede.lede: The United States hit a record high for new COVID-19 cases this week. In many areas with rising case counts, testing isn’t keeping up. Meanwhile, hospitalizations in regions with big outbreaks are increasing.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 18: The Regional Gap Widens

lede.lede: As cases and hospitalizations continue to drop in the early Northeast epicenters, they are rising—in some areas quite sharply—in the South and West. We look at the numbers and at the relationship between an increase in tests and a rise in case counts.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 11: Early Data from May Transmission

lede.lede: The news this week is mixed and highly regional. In the early US epicenter of the outbreak, cases continue to drop. In the southern and western United States, cases are on the rise, as are COVID-19 hospitalizations. And as always, the lag makes the data difficult to put into context.

blogContent.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The good news in COVID-19 data continued this week, as ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"new cases, hospitalizations, and deaths all dropped.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" For the seven-day period running January 28 to February 3, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"weekly new cases were down more than 16 percent","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" over the previous week, and dropped below one million for the first time since the week of November 5. This is still an astonishing number of new cases per week, but far better than the nearly 1.8 million cases ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"reported on the week of January 14","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/soaring-death-numbers-and-highly-regional-outbreaks-this-week-in-covid-19-data-jan-14"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". Tests also declined nationally, but by less than 3 percent, nowhere near enough to explain the steep drop in cases. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Hospitalizations have fallen rapidly for the past two weeks, but we have a long way to go: ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"The US now has about 91,000 people hospitalized with the virus as of yesterday","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", down about 40,000 from the country’s peak in early January, but still three times as many as before the fall/winter case surge.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"01dT4RssxAJ9XR1UCQll86","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"January was ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"the pandemic’s deadliest month so far","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2021/02/january-pandemic-deadliest-month/617898/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", but ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"reported COVID-19 deaths declined this week—the first weekly drop since mid-October that is not correlated with a holiday reporting period","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". Despite the decline, deaths remained arrestingly high: 21,288 were reported in the past seven days. The seven-day average for reported deaths is about 3,000 deaths per day. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The good news we’re seeing at the national level continues to reflect the reality of most US states as well. Ten states saw drops of more than 25 percent in new cases in the past week, based on the seven-day averages for January 27 and February 3. In another 32 states, new cases declined by at least 10 percent, and only a single state—Texas—posted a double-digit increase in the same period.  ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"33h08oLfnwX0S6evqTfs1j","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"These case declines are very welcome, but are taking place against a backdrop of very high viral transmission. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Despite the past three weeks of precipitous drops, US cases are still about three times higher than the previous lows following the summer’s Sun Belt surge","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"—and even during those lows, the United States was still reporting an average of more than 30,000 cases a day.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"4nuuYXmwUqEwIpsHBs6zvU","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Improvements continue in COVID-19 hospitalizations as well. Since the beginning of the year, we’ve seen hospitalization declines ranging from 33 to 44 percent in the Midwest, the West, and one part of the South—the East South Central sub-regional division, which includes Alabama, Kentucky, Mississippi, and Tennessee. The populous nine-state South Atlantic division has posted both the highest peak—in absolute numbers, not adjusted for population—and the smallest decline, at 14 percent.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"51e8TZ0JqFz1hFaErCYxbF","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Death reporting is extremely sensitive to holiday reporting delays—we saw substantial drops and recoveries in the seven-day average after Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Year’s Day, and Martin Luther King Jr. Day. Now, however, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"reported deaths appear to have entered a genuine decline, reflecting the drop in cases and hospitalizations","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"TT8zMu9HUGITNcufWsiM8","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Cases and deaths in American nursing homes and other long-term-care facilities appeared to spike in ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"our most recent week of data","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/nursing-homes-long-term-care-facilities"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" for these facilities, which runs January 22 through January 28—about a week behind our main dataset. This rise is an artifact of a reporting anomaly, however, due to ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Missouri’s","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/missouri/long-term-care"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" release of cumulative long-term-care data, for which the state provided no historical time-series. If we omit all 10,343 of Missouri’s  cumulative cases and 1,087 cumulative deaths from last week’s data, we can see that ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"the number of new cases and deaths associated with LTC outbreaks actually decreased slightly over the previous week","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":".","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"7DVzrdCrURkZ6jBANpWtIF","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The race and ethnicity data we collect from states also shows improving trends set against ongoing inequities. As we found in ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"a recent analysis","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/state-of-COVID-race-and-ethnicity-data"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", in most states, the racial and ethnic groups at higher risk of contracting or dying of COVID-19 have not changed, although the relative risk is lower than it was earlier in the pandemic. New cases per capita are declining across most communities we’re able to track, but disparities in the groups mostly likely to test positive—which in most US states are Black, Latinx, and Indigenous people—have not gone away. We have yet to see comprehensive action directed at addressing disparities in risk or outcomes in the United States. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Available vaccine data is ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"still missing critically important demographic information","marks":[{"type":"underline"},{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2021/02/01/covid-vaccine-race-ethnicity-data/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", but the data we do have shows ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"substantial inequities","marks":[{"type":"underline"},{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.kff.org/coronavirus-covid-19/issue-brief/latest-data-covid-19-vaccinations-cases-deaths-race-ethnicity/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" in the rollout so far.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"States we’re watching","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"California","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/california"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"’","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"s massive winter outbreak continues to ease. Cases and hospitalizations are dropping fast, and the seven-day average for reported deaths has begun to drop as well. Tests, too, are down considerably in California: On the seven-day average, about 100,000 fewer tests are being done each day in California now than were being performed a few weeks ago. In ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Sacramento County","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.abc10.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/covid-updates-northern-california-feb-3/103-fa104b67-3c6b-4c53-9acc-1a42d5136dcb"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", testing sites are only using a third of their total capacity. The statewide decline is likely in part a result of reduced demand following a drop in infections, but a sharp drop in testing is not what we’d like to see in a state where hospitalizations are still very high and multiple variants of SARS-CoV-2 are confirmed to be circulating. Statewide, genomic sequencing has discovered ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"133 cases of the B.1.1.7 variant first identified in the UK","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://deadline.com/2021/02/california-identifies-over-1000-cases-of-west-coast-covid-19-variants-1234685746/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", with a larger concentration in Southern California, and more than 1,000 cases of  B.1.429 and B.1.427—the variants first identified on the West Coast. In the Bay Area, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"a new variant originating from Brazil","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-02-02/coronavirus-variant-from-brazil-found-in-bay-area"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" has been identified. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"January was the","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":" deadliest month","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-02-01/january-deadliest-covid-month-la-california"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" of the pandemic for California, with 14,940 deaths, resulting in a cumulative 41,000 deaths. One in every 1,000 Californians have died due to the virus. Most of these deaths occurred in Los Angeles County, which has reported more than ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"17,000 total deaths","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://corona-virus.la/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" and an average of","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":" 6,200 new cases a day","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-02-01/january-deadliest-covid-month-la-california"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" over the past week. At the same time, LA County deaths among ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Latinx people","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://abc7news.com/health/latino-covid-deaths-in-la-county-up-100025-since-november-official-says/10276906/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" are occuring at three times the rate of white people, and Latinx deaths due to COVID-19 are up 1,000 percent in the county since November. The country’s ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"first two federally administered mass COVID-19 vaccination sites","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/federal-government-opening-first-mass-covid-19-vaccination-sites-california-n1256611"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" will open soon in California—one at the Oakland Coliseum and the other at California State University, Los Angeles. Both locations were chosen for their proximity to the  communities most harmed by the pandemic, according to Jeffrey Zients, coordinator of the Biden administration's COVID-19 response. California Governor Gavin Newsom announced last week that ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"the state’s vaccine allocation will soon prioritize residents 65 and older","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.kqed.org/news/11857538/so-angry-so-sad-so-scared-disability-advocates-say-states-new-vaccine-rollout-plan-leaves-them-behind"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"—rather than essential workers or younger people with underlying medical conditions, leading disability advocates to argue that health officials are neglecting vulnerable populations in a quest for greater efficiency.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"2FMSp9oTSoFti9Fju1RAf8","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Arizona","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/arizona"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" still has the highest per-capita COVID-19 hospitalizations in the country despite several weeks of hospitalization declines—a testament to how high the state’s numbers really were at the peak of its current outbreak. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Over half","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://ktar.com/story/3971465/arizona-reports-fewest-new-covid-19-cases-of-2021-with-214-deaths/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" of all ICU beds (53 percent) and 40 percent of inpatient beds were occupied by COVID-19 patients as of February 2. The state’s official positivity rate ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"continues to decline","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://ktar.com/story/3971465/arizona-reports-fewest-new-covid-19-cases-of-2021-with-214-deaths/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", with last week’s 16 percent the lowest since Thanksgiving, and the partial data for this week at 14 percent.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Arizona communities with high Latinx and Indigenous populations are disproportionately affected, according to an ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"in-depth report","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/feb/02/arizona-covid-19-surge-navajo-nation-mae-tso"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" by the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Guardian","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". Yuma County, which is home to many immigrants who live in communal housing, leads the state in cases per capita. In Coconino County, residents of Navajo Nation make up only 26 percent of the county’s population, but have accounted for 77 percent of the county’s deaths. More than two-thirds of those who have died of COVID-19 on Navajo Nation have been tribal members over the age of 60. The CDC ranks Arizona in the bottom 20 percent for ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"vaccine doses administered per capita","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". The state’s restaurants, bars, and gyms ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"remain open","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/feb/02/arizona-covid-19-surge-navajo-nation-mae-tso"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", and schools (including state universities) are holding in-person classes. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"6Qu3201MwbSkkS4xb85vhz","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Texas","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/texas"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", hospitalizations are declining, reflecting improvements in some regionalized outbreaks, but they remain very high. Texas is the second-most populous state in the country and is now fourth in the US for COVID-19 hospitalizations per capita. This translates to a lot of people in the hospital with the virus: about 11,000 today, compared to California’s 14,500. New case reporting remains erratic in Texas, and appears to be very closely tied to fluctuations in testing, which suggests that the state is still not doing enough tests to keep pace with the virus. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Laredo, a border city in South Texas, has been one of the hardest-hit hotspots nationwide for weeks and continues to suffer under the increased demand on their only two hospitals. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The ","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Texas Tribune","marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" reports","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.texastribune.org/2021/02/03/laredo-next-steps-coronavirus/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" that the state’s vaccine distribution is partially based on the number of healthcare workers in each region, resulting in decreased allocation to Laredo’s 260,000 residents, over 95 percent of whom are Hispanic, with nearly one third living below the poverty line. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Some residents and workers in Texas ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"long term care facilities","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.kxan.com/news/coronavirus/some-central-texas-assisted-living-facilities-have-not-received-covid-19-vaccines/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" have yet to get their first doses of vaccines, and only ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"2 million","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://abc13.com/covid-19-vaccine-rural-areas-without-texas-moderna/10171842/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" of the 8 million eligible Texas residents have been vaccinated so far. In the state’s prison system—where two in every 1,000 Texas inmates have already died of the virus—","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"5,500 vaccine doses have been administered","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.texastribune.org/2021/02/03/texas-prisons-coronavirus-vaccine/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", but the state has yet to administer a single dose to eligible inmates. According to the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Texas Tribune","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", the Texas Department of Criminal Justice has “repeatedly refused to provide information on when or how its older or medically vulnerable incarcerated population will be vaccinated.” ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"JU3HMCi7hi5EVBpSumsLz","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Alabama","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/alabama"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"’s hospitalizations per capita are in the top ten for the US, but the state is reporting by far the highest number of COVID-19 deaths per capita in the country. Alabama’s reporting has never been smooth, and it’s likely that backlogs play a role in the state’s soaring death numbers, but we will continue to watch the state closely. As of February 2, approximately 1 percent of the state had ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"received a full series of vaccinations","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.wsfa.com/2021/02/03/push-vaccinations-grows-covid-variants-emerge-alabama/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", although the numbers reported by the state ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"do not perfectly align","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://abcnews.go.com/Health/half-covid-19-vaccines-state-adminstered/story?id=75562816"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" with the numbers","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":" reported by the CDC","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". On February 8, Alabama will open vaccine distribution for more than 1 million people—those 65 and older and frontline workers—despite the fact that ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"demand already outpaces the supply","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.wvtm13.com/article/adph-launches-covid-19-vaccination-eligibility-check-and-scheduling-portal/35385874"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":".","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"7i1lhm0HRbqDxxJTWZBfGG","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Worryingly, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"New York","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/new-york"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"—the country’s fourth largest state by population—now has the second-highest per-capita hospitalizations for COVID-19, which means we’ll continue to keep a close eye on the Empire State. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The COVID Tracking Project is winding down","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"After compiling and analyzing state and territorial COVID-19 data for almost a year, we are now in the final phase of our work and will shut down data collection on March 7. Until then, we will continue to publish daily updates to our data and share our weekly analyses. Once data compilation has ended, our researchers will spend two more months documenting and analyzing state and federal data before the project winds down in May. You can learn more about our plans—and our reasons for ending our work—in our ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"announcement post","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/covid-tracking-project-end-march-7"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" from earlier this week.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":" ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

image.title: Nationwide COVID-19 Metrics by Week, Mar 12–Feb 3
image.description: 4 bar charts showing weekly COVID-19 data over time for the US. Tests, cases, average hospitalizations, and deaths all fell this week, with cases falling over 16% from a week prior.

image.title: 7-Day Average Cases: Feb 3 vs Jan 27
image.description: Block map of US states showing the change in 7-day average COVID-19 cases over the last week. Many states saw cases decline over 25% week over week, while only Texas saw a rise of over 10%.

image.title: Weekly cases per million people by sub-region, Mar 12–Feb 3
image.description: Bubble chart showing weekly COVID-19 cases per million people for each US sub-region. Cases across the sub-regions grew alarmingly in December and January but are beginning to subside from those high levels in early February.

image.title: US Currently Hospitalized with COVID-19, Jan 1–Feb 3
image.description: Line charts showing the change in currently hospitalized with COVID-19 in each US sub-region since January 1. All sub-regions have seen hospitalizations decline by at least 14%.

image.title: US Daily Reported Deaths, 7-Day Average, Mar 12–Feb 3
image.description: Bar chart of daily deaths from COVID-19 in the US with a 7-day average line. Deaths have begun to drift downward after hitting their all-time 7-day average peak in early January.

image.title: US COVID-19 Metrics in Long-Term-Care Facilities, Missouri Excluded, May 28–Jan 28
image.description: 3 bar weekly bar charts showing US COVID-19 metrics in long-term-care facilities, excluding Missouri, May 28 through Jan 28. New cases have declined in these facilities  for 3 straight weeks and are now below 10,000 weekly.

image.title: California COVID-19 Metrics, 7-Day Average, Oct 1–Feb 3
image.description: 4 bar charts showing daily COVID-19 metrics in California with 7-day average lines. Tests, cases, hospitalizations, and deaths are all declining, thought cases much more quickly than the other metrics.

image.title: Arizona COVID-19 Metrics, 7-Day Average, Oct 1–Feb 3
image.description: 4 bar charts showing daily COVID-19 metrics in Arizona with 7-day average lines. Cases and Hospitalizations have seen significant declines over the past week while deaths remain stubbornly high.

image.title: Texas COVID-19 Metrics, 7-Day Average, Oct 1–Feb 3
image.description: 4 bar charts showing daily COVID-19 tests, cases, hospitalizations, and deaths in Texas with 7-day average lines. Cases have yet to see a major decline, though hospitalizations have turned in the right direction in recent weeks.

image.title: Alabama COVID-19 Metrics, 7-Day Average, Oct 1–Feb 3
image.description: 4 bar charts showing daily COVID-19 tests, cases, hospitalizations, and deaths in Alabama with 7-day average lines. Deaths remain quite high though all three other metrics have declined significantly.

lede.lede: Cases and hospitalizations continue to drop, and now COVID-19 deaths finally appear to be declining.
